newsitem.title: USA: Northrop Grumman debt holds on to tighter spreads.
newsitem.headline: Northrop Grumman debt holds on to tighter spreads.

text.p: Northrop Grumman Corp debt tightened another three basis points for a total of 18 basis points since news of its merger with aerospace giant Lockheed Martin Corp hit the market, traders said.
"Before news of the merger Northrop's debt was quoted 75 basis points bid, with no offer," said one high-grade trader. "Since then, it has tightened substantially."
The defense contractor's 7.0 percent paper due 2006 was bid 57 basis points, narrowing further from Thursday's closing level of 60 basis points bid, traders said.
No change was seen by market players in Lockheed Martin's seven-to-10-year debt after the merger news.
Last Thursday, the two firms announced their plans to merge in an $11.6 billion stock transaction.

The deal would allow Lockheed Martin to emerge as the sole remaining competitor of aerospace giant Boeing Co, which is in the process of buying McDonnell Douglass Corp, in a deal valued at $14 billion.
After news of the merger, Moody's Investors Service Inc affirmed Lockheed Martin's A3 senior debt rating, while placing Northrop Grumman's Baa3 senior debt under review for a possible upgrade.

After reviewing the impact of the transaction, Moody's concluded that the technological synergies and expected cost savings from the combination would make Lockheed Martin a more competitive global defense contractor.
However, another credit rating agency, Standard & Poor's, said it may cut Lockheed Martin's BBB-plus senior debt rating.
S&P also placed Northrop Grumman's BBB-minus senior debt rating under review for a possible upgrade.

"Basically, you have two companies who were growing into their respective ratings," said Martin Knoblowitz, a defense analyst at S&P, in response to the rating. "Both made substantial debt-financed acquisitions during 1996, so they were not up to the metrics, so to speak, and now you have a potential merger on top of that."
If both firms were growing into their respective ratings, current cash flows were "sub-par," making additional outflows necessary, but any such timing was unclear, Knoblowitz said.
"That's what we have to discuss with them in terms of resolving Creditwatch," he added.
Meanwhile, amid a quiet post-holiday trading session, market participants kept a watchful eye on the companies' bonds for any further movement as many players headed back from their extended holiday.
